message_1:
A message is encrypted using a simple substitution cipher, where each letter is replaced by another letter in the alphabet. The encrypted message has the following frequency distribution: 

A - 0.12; B - 0.09; C - 0.14; D - 0.04; E - 0.22; F - 0.06; G - 0.08; H - 0.05; I - 0.02; J - 0.03; K - 0.00; L - 0.06; M - 0.07; N - 0.10; O - 0.03; P - 0.01; Q - 0.00; R - 0.10; S - 0.09; T - 0.08; U - 0.01; V - 0.00; W - 0.01; X - 0.00; Y - 0.04; Z - 0.01.

Assuming that the letter frequency distribution of the unencrypted message is the same as that of the English language, determine the original frequency distribution of the message.
message_2:
To determine the original frequency distribution of the message, we can compare the given encrypted frequency distribution with the standard English letter frequency distribution. The standard English letter frequency distribution is as follows (rounded to two decimal places):

E - 0.12; T - 0.09; A - 0.08; O - 0.08; I - 0.07; N - 0.07; S - 0.06; H - 0.06; R - 0.06; D - 0.04; L - 0.04; C - 0.03; U - 0.03; M - 0.02; W - 0.02; F - 0.02; G - 0.02; Y - 0.02; P - 0.02; B - 0.01; V - 0.01; K - 0.01; J - 0.01; X - 0.01; Q - 0.01; Z - 0.01.

Now, we can match the encrypted frequency distribution with the standard English frequency distribution by comparing the frequencies:

A - E (0.12)
B - T (0.09)
C - A (0.14)

E - O (0.22)
F - I (0.06)
G - N (0.08)

K - (0.00) - No match found
L - L (0.06)

N - U (0.10)
O - M (0.03)
P - W (0.01)
Q - (0.00) - No match found
R - F (0.10)
S - G (0.09)
T - Y (0.08)
U - P (0.01)
V - (0.00) - No match found
W - B (0.01)
X - (0.00) - No match found
Y - V (0.04)
Z - K (0.01)

The original frequency distribution of the message is:

A - 0.14; B - 0.01; C - 0.07; D - 0.04; E - 0.12; F - 0.10; G - 0.09; H - 0.02; I - 0.06; J - 0.01; K - 0.01; L - 0.06; M - 0.03; N - 0.08; O - 0.22; P - 0.01; Q - 0.01; R - 0.03; S - 0.05; T - 0.09; U - 0.10; V - 0.04; W - 0.01; X - 0.01; Y - 0.08; Z - 0.01.
